elements.title: Persistent Rule Verification Strip
elements.problem: June carries non-standard, protection-driven rules (utility cap at $40 with guest-paid overage, vetting documentation requirements, deposit and cleaning fee amounts) that she needs to verify are accurately captured at every phase. In the call, she asked the identical fee question twice (07:32 and 10:59), demonstrating that verbal feedback does not persist in memory. When critical rules are communicated once and then disappear -- as a toast notification, a confirmation email, or a spoken promise -- the host cannot verify them at the moment of decision. This forces the host to re-ask, re-check, or lose trust silently. The information architecture problem is that host-defined rules are treated as input data (captured once, stored invisibly) rather than as persistent reference information (always visible where relevant).
elements.solution: Architect a persistent 'Rule Verification Strip' -- a fixed, scannable summary of all host-defined rules -- that appears on every screen where those rules are actionable. On the listing editor, this strip shows rent ($2,690), deposit ($2,500), cleaning fee ($140), utility cap ($40 / guest pays overage) as always-visible fields, not as collapsed sections. On the proposal review screen, the same strip appears with verification indicators (checkmarks or match/mismatch flags) confirming that the proposal terms align with the host's stated rules. On the active lease dashboard, the strip persists as a reference panel showing which rules are currently in effect. The strip uses the host's own language, not platform terminology. The architecture principle: host-defined rules are reference information, not input data, and reference information must be persistently visible at every decision point.

evidence.quote: Are there any fees? Anything? No. There shouldn't be any fees on your company. [asked identically twice in the same call]
evidence.insight: The same critical question asked twice in a single conversation proves that one-time verbal feedback does not persist. The information architecture must compensate by making critical rules permanently visible, not temporarily confirmed.

evidence.quote: The electric bill, because people have been ridiculous... I believe it's only covered up to 40, the first $40 I pay and they have to pay different... I had to start protecting myself cause it was getting too much.
evidence.insight: The utility cap is a protection rule born from painful experience. Its persistent visibility is not an information convenience -- it is a trust requirement. If the host cannot verify the rule is captured, she cannot trust the platform is protecting her.

evidence.source: microinteractions-rules-feedback.txt, Ch. 4, Feedback Illuminates the Rules, p. 86
evidence.quote: Feedback Illuminates the Rules.
evidence.insight: Saffer's principle that rules are invisible until feedback makes them visible directly supports the architecture of persistent rule displays. Hidden rules create the same risk as the iPhone silent-mode alarm: the host does not know what the platform is or is not enforcing.

evidence.quote: Microcopy.
evidence.insight: The rule strip must use microcopy that mirrors the host's language. 'You cover the first $40 of electric. Your guest pays anything above that.' -- not 'Utility allocation threshold: $40 (variable surcharge enabled).'

elements.hierarchy_principle: Host-defined rules are primary information on every screen where those rules affect a decision. They sit above action buttons and above guest details. The hierarchy is: (1) your rules as you stated them, (2) how the current situation maps to those rules, (3) actions you can take. Rules are not settings to be found in a menu; they are the lens through which the host evaluates everything else.
elements.disclosure_pattern: No progressive disclosure for host-defined rules. They are always fully visible on any screen where they are relevant. Progressive disclosure applies only to the detail behind each rule: tapping the utility cap shows the full policy text; tapping the deposit shows the refund conditions. The summary is always present; the detail is one tap away.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 5 rules displayed simultaneously in the strip. Each rule is expressed in one line of no more than 12 words, using the host's own vocabulary. If the host has more than 5 rules, the strip shows the 5 most recently relevant and offers a 'See all rules' expansion. Numeric values must be displayed as numerals, not spelled out.
scan_order: Rule labels in bold (rent, deposit, cleaning fee, utility cap)
Numeric values beside each label
Verification indicator (checkmark or flag) beside each value
Action button below the strip
exclude: Platform fee structure (the host asked about fees twice; this confusion must not be recreated by showing platform-side fee math on the host's rule strip)
Guest payment schedule details (this is guest-facing information, not host-rule information)
Historical changes to rules (version history belongs in settings, not on the active rule strip)

elements.title: Single-Surface Proposal Decision Screen
elements.problem: June's proposal evaluation requires simultaneous verification of multiple conditions: guest vetting status, pricing accuracy, utility cap inclusion, calendar impact on other platforms, and lease duration. In the call, these were addressed sequentially over several minutes because phone conversations are linear. But a digital proposal screen does not need to be linear. The information architecture risk is that the proposal screen fragments these verification points across multiple tabs, modals, or sub-pages, forcing the host into a sequential hunt for information that should be available in parallel. June said 'I need to know who they are and what type of people' (06:04) and 'tell them it's something they have to decide quickly' (05:40) -- she needs speed AND thoroughness, which are only compatible when all decision inputs are on one surface.
elements.solution: Architect the proposal review as a single-surface decision screen with all verification points visible without scrolling below the fold on desktop, or within one scroll-length on mobile. The screen is divided into three zones: (1) Guest Zone -- guest names, employment status, vetting completion indicator (checkmark + 'Vetted by Split Lease'), and a link to full profiles. This is not a separate page; it is an inline card. (2) Terms Zone -- the host's rules from their listing displayed alongside the proposed terms, with match indicators. Rent: $2,690 (matches listing). Duration: 3 months (with extension option). Start date: March 2nd. Utility cap: $40 / guest pays overage (confirmed). (3) Action Zone -- calendar impact notice ('Block these dates on your other platforms: Furnished Finder, [other]'), payment guarantee badge, and a single Accept / Decline action pair. No multi-step wizard. No 'Review terms' link that opens another page.

evidence.quote: I need to know who they are and what type of people. I don't want Connie in the house.
evidence.insight: Guest identity verification is a non-negotiable precondition for proposal acceptance. If the host has to navigate away from the proposal to find vetting information, the decision flow is broken.

evidence.quote: Tell them it's something they have to decide quickly because I would have to block it on the different platforms I have it on.
evidence.insight: The host's urgency means the proposal screen must minimize time-to-decision. Every click away from the primary screen adds seconds that a time-pressured host will not tolerate.

evidence.quote: We've vetted both Ariel and Amber... payments are guaranteed to you as the landlord... even in the case that a guest missed a payment or didn't pay, you still get paid.
evidence.insight: Vetting status and payment guarantee are the two strongest trust signals. On the proposal screen, they must be visual indicators (badges, checkmarks), not paragraphs of explanation that the host must read and interpret.

evidence.quote: Visual feedback is the most effective form.
evidence.insight: Saffer's hierarchy of feedback effectiveness (visual > audio > haptic) means the proposal screen must communicate verification through visual indicators -- status badges, color-coded match/mismatch -- not through text descriptions.

elements.hierarchy_principle: The proposal screen hierarchy follows the host's decision tree from L1: (1) Who are these people? (guest identity and vetting -- primary), (2) Do the terms match my rules? (pricing and conditions -- secondary), (3) What do I need to do next? (calendar blocking and accept/decline action -- tertiary). Guest information is primary because June's first and most emotional concern is tenant quality. Terms verification is secondary because it is a factual check. Action is tertiary because it only matters after verification is complete.
elements.disclosure_pattern: The proposal screen itself is fully disclosed -- no progressive reveal for the three zones. Within each zone, progressive disclosure applies: the guest card shows name, photo, employment, and vetting badge at the top level; tapping opens the full profile with LinkedIn, credit summary, and references. Terms show summary values; tapping opens the full lease agreement draft. The principle: the decision-relevant summary is always visible; the evidentiary detail is one tap deep.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 7 data points visible without interaction: guest name(s), vetting status, rent amount, deposit amount, lease duration, start date, payment guarantee indicator. All additional information (utility cap detail, full profile, lease text) is accessible but not displayed by default. The screen must be comprehensible in under 30 seconds of scanning.
scan_order: Guest names and vetting badge (top-left zone)
Pricing summary with match indicators (middle zone)
Lease duration and start date (middle zone, right column)
Payment guarantee badge (bottom zone, prominent)
Accept / Decline buttons (bottom zone, final)
exclude: Platform fee breakdown (the host pays no fees; showing fee math adds confusion)
Internal vetting methodology (the host wants the result, not the process; methodology belongs in a 'How we vet' help article, not on the decision screen)
Other available guests (the proposal is about these specific guests; showing alternatives creates decision paralysis)

elements.title: Agent-Continuity First Impression on Platform Entry
elements.problem: June's entire relationship with Split Lease is mediated by Bryant. The platform's first digital touchpoint is an email link Bryant promised to send (13:27). When June clicks that link, she will see a screen that either confirms the continuity of her conversation with Bryant or presents a completely unfamiliar interface. The information architecture challenge is that the platform's entry screen is designed generically -- for any host arriving from any channel -- rather than specifically for a host who has just completed a call with a named agent about specific properties. June is personally depleted ('going through a lot of stuff myself,' 06:33) and time-constrained ('a couple of zoom calls today,' 00:19). If the first screen requires her to orient herself to a new context rather than recognizing the context Bryant established, she will close the tab.
elements.solution: Architect the platform's first screen for agent-referred hosts as a personalized continuation screen, not a generic onboarding page. The screen's headline is 'Bryant prepared your listing' -- not 'Welcome to Split Lease.' Below the headline: the property address June discussed, the pricing Bryant confirmed ($2,690/month, $2,500 deposit, $140 cleaning), and a preview of the listing as Bryant entered it. The primary action is 'Review and Confirm' -- not 'Create Your Listing.' Bryant's name and photo appear in a sidebar or header element, with a 'Text Bryant' link. The information architecture principle: the first screen the host sees must answer 'Am I in the right place?' and 'Did they get my information right?' before asking 'What do you want me to do?'

evidence.quote: I'll get those listings created. I can send you an email with a link to our site and you can expect that shortly after the call.
evidence.insight: The entire onboarding is framed as a delivery from Bryant. The first screen must match this expectation: something was prepared for you, here it is. Not: here is our platform, now create something.

evidence.quote: I been going through a lot of stuff myself. I'm sorry.
evidence.insight: A depleted host arriving from a link in an email has near-zero tolerance for orientation cost. The information architecture must eliminate the 'where am I and what do I do?' phase entirely by showing familiar content immediately.

evidence.quote: Make the trigger something the target users will recognize as a trigger in context... Have the trigger initiate the same action every time.
evidence.insight: June's recognized trigger is Bryant. The platform's first screen must be recognizable as a Bryant-initiated artifact. If it looks like a generic SaaS onboarding page, it is an unrecognized trigger and will not initiate engagement.

evidence.source: microinteractions-rules-feedback.txt, Ch. 3, Don't Start from Zero, p. 64
evidence.quote: Don't Start from Zero.
evidence.insight: The first screen must show what the platform already knows (from Bryant's data entry): property details, pricing, terms. Starting from a blank form violates Don't Start from Zero and wastes the data Bryant already captured.

elements.hierarchy_principle: On the entry screen, the hierarchy is: (1) Agent identity and continuity signal (Bryant's name/photo + 'prepared for you' framing -- primary), (2) Property and pricing summary as the agent entered it (the familiar data -- secondary), (3) Review/confirm action (the minimal ask -- tertiary). Account creation, platform tour, or feature explanation are NOT in this hierarchy. They are deferred until after the host has confirmed their listing.
elements.disclosure_pattern: The entry screen discloses only what Bryant discussed in the call: property details, pricing, and the listing preview. Platform features, other hosts' testimonials, and how-it-works explanations are suppressed on the first visit. They are disclosed only after the host completes the listing confirmation. The principle: prove you listened before you sell.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The entry screen displays a maximum of 4 information groups: (1) Agent identity (name + photo), (2) Property summary (address + unit type), (3) Pricing summary (rent + deposit + cleaning fee), (4) One primary action button ('Review Your Listing'). No sidebar navigation, no feature menu, no secondary calls to action on the first screen. Total word count for scannable content: under 60 words.
scan_order: Agent name and 'prepared for you' headline (top)
Property address and unit identifier (below headline)
Pricing summary in the host's stated numbers (middle)
'Review Your Listing' button (bottom)
exclude: Platform feature explanations (the host is not evaluating the platform; she is reviewing her listing)
Account creation form (defer until after listing confirmation; use the email link as temporary authentication)
Other hosts' testimonials or social proof (June is a real estate agent; peer testimonials do not accelerate her decision -- her own data accuracy does)
Navigation menu or dashboard preview (the host has one task: review what Bryant prepared)

elements.title: Cross-Platform Calendar Impact Disclosure at Commitment Points
elements.problem: June operates on Furnished Finder, other unnamed platforms, and potentially Split Lease. Every commitment on Split Lease (accepting a proposal, extending a lease) has an invisible external cost: manual calendar blocking on other platforms. June states this explicitly: 'Tell them it's something they have to decide quickly because I would have to block it on the different platforms I have it on' (05:40). The information architecture problem is that the platform's commitment flows (proposal acceptance, lease extension) treat the commitment as a closed-system action -- 'Accept this proposal' -- without acknowledging or surfacing the cross-platform consequences. The host is left to remember, on her own, that accepting on Split Lease means she needs to go block dates on Furnished Finder and elsewhere. This hidden cost creates anxiety at the decision point and risk of double-booking after it.
elements.solution: At every commitment point, insert a cross-platform impact disclosure panel immediately before the action button. This panel reads: 'When you accept, remember to block [dates] on your other platforms.' If the host has previously indicated which platforms she uses (captured during onboarding or listing creation), the panel names them specifically: 'Block March 2 - June 2 on Furnished Finder.' The panel is not a blocker -- it does not require the host to confirm she has blocked -- but it is architecturally positioned as the last thing the host sees before pressing Accept, making it impossible to miss. For lease extensions, the same pattern applies: 'Your lease is extending to September 2. Update your availability on Furnished Finder.' Long-term, this panel becomes the integration point for calendar sync automation.

evidence.quote: Tell them it's something they have to decide quickly because I would have to block it on the different platforms I have it on.
evidence.insight: Cross-platform calendar management is a real, immediate operational cost that the host is already aware of. The information architecture must acknowledge this cost at the point of commitment, not leave it as the host's private burden.

evidence.quote: I'm surprised I've never heard of [Split Lease] as well as I'm a real estate agent as well. I find everybody my own.
evidence.insight: June is a multi-platform professional who manages her own pipeline. The platform must respect this reality by acknowledging that Split Lease is one channel among many, not the host's only channel.

evidence.quote: Absorb Complexity.
evidence.insight: Saffer's principle: the system should handle complexity internally. Even when full automation (calendar sync) is not yet built, the information architecture can absorb the cognitive complexity by surfacing the reminder at the right moment -- so the host does not need to remember on her own.

evidence.source: microinteractions-rules-feedback.txt, Ch. 4, Feedback Illuminates the Rules, p. 86
evidence.quote: Feedback Illuminates the Rules.
evidence.insight: The cross-platform blocking obligation is a hidden rule of accepting a Split Lease proposal. Feedback must illuminate it: the host should see the external consequence of her action before she takes it, not discover it after.

elements.hierarchy_principle: The cross-platform impact disclosure sits between the terms summary and the action button. It is tertiary information (after guest details and terms verification) but it is architecturally positioned as a gate before the action. The hierarchy at the commitment point is: (1) Verified terms, (2) Cross-platform impact notice, (3) Accept/Decline action. The impact notice is visually distinct (different background color, icon of a calendar with multiple platform logos) to prevent it from blending into the terms summary.
elements.disclosure_pattern: The cross-platform impact panel appears only at commitment points (proposal acceptance, lease extension, lease termination). It does not appear on browse screens, listing views, or status dashboards. Within the panel, the specific platforms and dates are fully disclosed if the host has provided platform information; otherwise, a generic reminder ('Update your other platforms') appears with a prompt to add platform names for future specificity.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The panel contains a maximum of 2 lines of text: one identifying the dates to block, one naming the platforms. No paragraph explanations. No links to calendar sync setup (that belongs in settings, not in the commitment flow). The visual design uses an icon + short text pattern to keep scan time under 3 seconds.
scan_order: Calendar icon with platform indicators (left side of panel)
Date range to block in bold (center of panel)
Platform names (right side of panel or second line)
Accept / Decline buttons immediately below
exclude: Calendar sync setup instructions (this belongs in settings, not at the commitment point -- adding setup complexity to a decision moment increases abandonment)
Other platforms' listing details (the host knows her own listings; showing Furnished Finder screenshots or links is unnecessary and distracting)
Double-booking warnings or liability language (the panel is a helpful reminder, not a legal warning -- tone matters)

elements.title: Adaptive Lease Health Dashboard with Ambient-to-Alert Escalation
elements.problem: June's dominant active-lease anxiety is utility abuse ($100-$200 bills from guests running heat with windows open). Her $40 cap is a rule she needs continuously verified throughout the lease, not just at listing creation. But the information architecture challenge extends beyond utilities: the active lease requires ongoing confirmation of payment receipt, rule enforcement, and lease status. If the platform provides no active-lease information architecture, the host must either (a) monitor manually, recreating the anxiety the platform was supposed to eliminate, or (b) trust blindly, which contradicts the protection-driven mindset June has developed from negative experiences. Saffer's Long Loops principle (Ch. 5, p. 117) requires that recurring microinteractions adapt over time -- the same static dashboard for month 1 and month 6 fails to serve either the anxious new host or the confident experienced one.
elements.solution: Architect the active lease view as an adaptive health dashboard with two modes: ambient (everything is fine) and alert (something needs attention). In ambient mode, the dashboard shows a compact summary: payment status (green checkmark + 'February payment deposited'), utility status (green indicator + 'Utility usage: $32 / $40 cap'), and lease timeline (progress bar showing time remaining). This ambient mode requires zero interaction -- the host glances and is reassured. In alert mode, triggered when a threshold is crossed (utility exceeds $40, payment is delayed, lease end is approaching), the dashboard surfaces specific information: the overage amount, the action the platform is taking (guest notification, overage charge), and what the host needs to do (if anything). The adaptation principle: new leases start with more frequent and detailed feedback; as the lease progresses without issues, feedback frequency decreases and detail compresses. This mirrors Saffer's Long Loop guidance.

evidence.quote: I have had bills of a hundred, $200. I was like, what are you doing in the apartment?... the heat is on while the windows are open. They're not home, running, you know, all of that stuff. So I had to start protecting myself cause it was getting too much.
evidence.insight: Utility monitoring is the host's primary anxiety during the active lease. The dashboard must provide continuous, ambient confirmation that the utility rule is being enforced -- silence is not reassurance for a host who has been burned.

evidence.quote: Payments are guaranteed to you as the landlord... even in the case that a guest missed a payment or didn't pay, you still get paid.
evidence.insight: The payment guarantee is a verbal promise that must become a recurring visual confirmation. Each payment cycle, the host should see positive proof that the guarantee is being honored -- not just the absence of a problem.

evidence.quote: Long Loops.
evidence.insight: Active leases span months. Saffer's Long Loop principle requires the microinteraction to evolve over time: more detailed early on (building trust), more ambient later (confirming established trust). A static dashboard violates this by providing the same information density regardless of lease maturity.

evidence.source: microinteractions-rules-feedback.txt, Ch. 5, Spring-Loaded and One-off Modes, p. 111-113
evidence.quote: Modes... Spring-Loaded and One-off Modes.
evidence.insight: The alert mode is spring-loaded: it activates when a threshold is crossed (utility overage, payment delay) and deactivates when the issue is resolved. The host should see the dashboard shift from ambient to alert and back, providing clear feedback about the current state.

elements.hierarchy_principle: On the lease dashboard, the hierarchy follows the host's anxiety order: (1) Payment status (the guarantee promise -- primary, because money is the ultimate concern), (2) Utility usage vs. cap (the protection rule -- secondary, because it is the host's stated fear), (3) Lease timeline and upcoming events (renewal, end date -- tertiary, because these are future-oriented). In alert mode, the alerted item moves to the top of the hierarchy regardless of its default position.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Ambient mode is the default view: compact, glanceable, 3 indicators. Alert mode progressively discloses detail only when a threshold is crossed. The host does not need to dig for information in ambient mode; the information finds the host in alert mode. Monthly summary emails mirror the dashboard's current mode: a calm summary for ambient months, a detailed action-required email for alert months.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Ambient mode: 3 status indicators, each 1 line, total scan time under 5 seconds. Alert mode: maximum 2 additional lines per alerted item explaining the issue and the platform's response. No more than 1 active alert displayed at a time without explicit expansion. Historical data (past months' utility usage, payment history) is available via a 'History' link but not displayed on the primary dashboard surface.
scan_order: Payment status indicator with amount and date (top row)
Utility usage indicator with bar showing current vs. cap (second row)
Lease timeline progress bar with days remaining (third row)
Alert banner if any threshold is crossed (replaces or overlays the relevant row)
exclude: Guest activity details (the host does not need to see when the guest logs in or browses -- only rule-relevant behavior like utility usage)
Platform operational updates (system maintenance, feature announcements do not belong on the lease health dashboard)
Comparative data from other hosts ('Average utility usage in your area') -- this introduces noise and social comparison that does not serve the host's monitoring goal

elements.title: Multi-Unit Listing Architecture with Building-Level Inheritance
elements.problem: June owns a three-family house with at least two listable apartments and proactively offered to list both (09:36). Multi-unit hosts face an information architecture problem: rules, pricing defaults, and property details exist at two levels -- the building level (address, house rules, utility policy, neighborhood description) and the unit level (floor, bedrooms, specific rent, unit photos). If the information architecture treats each listing as an independent entity, the host must re-enter building-level information for every unit. This violates Saffer's Don't Start from Zero principle and creates inconsistency risk (different utility cap phrasing across units, slightly different addresses). The L1 element works-004 identifies this as a process problem; the information architecture challenge is how to structure the screens so the host sees and edits building-level data once and unit-level data per unit.
elements.solution: Architect listing creation as a two-tier information structure. The first tier is the Building Profile: address, neighborhood description, transit access (June mentioned '3/2/9 express downtown'), house rules, utility policy, and deposit amount. This is entered once and shared across all units. The second tier is the Unit Profile: unit identifier (Apt 1, Apt 2), bedrooms, rent amount, unit-specific photos, and any unit-specific overrides to building-level defaults. When the host creates a second listing, the screen shows the Building Profile as pre-filled and read-only (with an 'Edit building info' link), and presents only the Unit Profile fields for input. The scan pattern is: building info (confirmed) above a divider line, unit info (editable) below. This architecture makes it visually clear what is shared and what is unique.

evidence.quote: It's something like join in with, and you can list both of my apartments.
evidence.insight: The host expects to list both units in a single interaction context. The information architecture must support this by making the second listing feel like an extension of the first, not a repetition.

evidence.quote: The electric bill... it's only covered up to 40, the first $40 I pay and they have to pay different.
evidence.insight: The utility cap is a building-level rule that applies to all units in June's three-family house. The architecture must capture it once at the building level and apply it to all units, not ask for it per unit.

evidence.source: microinteractions-rules-feedback.txt, Ch. 3, Don't Start from Zero, p. 64
evidence.quote: Don't Start from Zero.
evidence.insight: The second listing must start from the first listing's building-level data, not from a blank form. Saffer's principle directly mandates that the information architecture distinguish between data that is already known (building-level) and data that is genuinely new (unit-level).

evidence.source: microinteractions-rules-feedback.txt, Ch. 3, Limited Options and Smart Defaults, p. 69
evidence.quote: Limited Options and Smart Defaults.
evidence.insight: For the second unit, the smart default for every building-level field is 'same as your other unit.' The host should only see fields that are likely to differ (rent, bedrooms, photos). This limits options to the genuinely variable inputs.

elements.hierarchy_principle: On the listing creation screen for a second unit, the hierarchy is: (1) Building Profile summary (pre-filled, read-only, shown as confirmed context -- primary because it establishes that the platform already knows this), (2) Unit-specific fields requiring input (editable, highlighted -- secondary because this is the host's actual task), (3) Preview of the complete listing combining both tiers (tertiary, accessible via 'Preview' button). The building profile is visually distinguished from the unit profile through background color or section framing, making the two-tier structure immediately apparent.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Building-level data is disclosed as a collapsed, confirmed summary on the second listing screen. It is expandable for editing but defaults to showing just key values (address, utility policy, deposit) in a compact format. Unit-level data is fully disclosed as editable fields. On the first listing screen, both tiers are fully editable because there is no building profile yet. The architecture adapts: the first listing is full-form; the second listing is delta-only.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The second listing form presents a maximum of 5 unit-specific fields requiring input: unit identifier, bedrooms, rent amount, unit photos, and one optional field for unit-specific notes. Building-level data (potentially 8-10 fields) is summarized in 3-4 lines of confirmed text above the unit fields. Total cognitive load for the second listing: approximately 40% of the first listing.
scan_order: Building summary banner ('123 W 131st St, Harlem -- Utility: $40 cap -- Deposit: $2,500') at top
Unit identifier field (first editable input)
Rent amount field (the most important unit-specific variable)
Photos upload area
'Create Listing' button at bottom
exclude: Building-level fields as editable inputs on the second listing screen (they appear as confirmed summary; editing them opens the building profile, not inline form fields)
Market comparison data during listing creation ('Other hosts in Harlem charge...') -- this introduces decision complexity at a moment that should be about accuracy, not optimization
Listing analytics or performance previews ('Expected views per month') -- this is retention-phase information, not creation-phase information
